creator: sanry@now.net.cn
text:
[Mon Jul 05 21:49:54 2004] [warn] pid file /usr/local/apache2/logs/httpd.pid 
overwritten -- Unclean shutdown of previous Apache run?
[Mon Jul 05 21:49:54 2004] [notice] Apache/2.0.50 (Unix) mod_ssl/2.0.50 
OpenSSL/0.9.7d mod_jk2/2.0.4 PHP/4.3.7 configured -- resuming normal operations
[Tue Jul 06 07:04:10 2004] [notice] child pid 2029 exit signal Segmentation 
fault (11)
[Tue Jul 06 10:35:00 2004] [notice] child pid 12275 exit signal Segmentation 
fault (11)
[Tue Jul 06 11:25:34 2004] [notice] child pid 25556 exit signal Segmentation 
fault (11)
[Tue Jul 06 11:32:15 2004] [warn] pid file /usr/local/apache2/logs/httpd.pid 
overwritten -- Unclean shutdown of previous Apache run?
[Tue Jul 06 11:32:16 2004] [notice] Apache/2.0.50 (Unix) mod_ssl/2.0.50 
OpenSSL/0.9.7d mod_jk2/2.0.4 PHP/4.3.7 configured -- resuming normal operations
[Tue Jul 06 11:38:26 2004] [warn] pid file /usr/local/apache2/logs/httpd.pid 
overwritten -- Unclean shutdown of previous Apache run?
[Tue Jul 06 11:38:26 2004] [notice] Apache/2.0.50 (Unix) mod_ssl/2.0.50 
OpenSSL/0.9.7d mod_jk2/2.0.4 PHP/4.3.7 configured -- resuming normal operations
[Tue Jul 06 17:20:19 2004] [notice] child pid 25577 exit signal Segmentation 
fault (11)
[Tue Jul 06 20:30:00 2004] [notice] child pid 9417 exit signal Segmentation 
fault (11)
[Tue Jul 06 20:36:33 2004] [warn] pid file /usr/local/apache2/logs/httpd.pid 
overwritten -- Unclean shutdown of previous Apache run?
[Tue Jul 06 20:36:34 2004] [notice] Apache/2.0.50 (Unix) mod_ssl/2.0.50 
OpenSSL/0.9.7d mod_jk2/2.0.4 PHP/4.3.7 configured -- resuming normal operations

Can you get a backtrace?  Add "CoredumpDirectory /var/tmp" to your httpd.conf, and:

# ulimit -c unlimited
# bin/apachectl start

then attach to this bug report the output of the following command:

# gdb bin/httpd /var/tmp/core.<xxxxx>
...
(gdb) backtrace

for one of the core files produced.
creator: jorton@redhat.com
jorton@redhat.com
text: If you can't get a backtrace here there's not much we can do.

I wonder if this has anything to do with the problem I have.  When I start
Apache (2.0.50 mod_ssl mod_perl) without ssl (No -DSSL) the server runs fine,
nice and snappy.  When I start it with SSL, the server's load average
immediately goes up to 4.0 and stays there.  After doing some load testing over
HTTPS using Jmeter, the load went up to 32.0 and very, very slowly dropped back
down to 4 after the testing was finished.  I've tested this out on two different
Dell PowerEdge 2650 servers running RHEL 3 and have gotten identical results.
Just as additional information, mod_ssl was built against openssl 0.9.7a.
creator: adriano.caloiaro@ccci.org

text:
Can you identify using "top" whether there are httpd process spinning eating
CPU, and the run "strace -p" on those process IDs to see what they are doing?
creator: jorton@redhat.com

text:
I'm having the same problem... I tried adding "CoredumpDirectory /var/tmp" to my
/etc/apache2/conf/apache2.conf file, then doing what you showed above... but no
cores are generated... Is there something else I'm missing?

Here's my configuration:
Apache/2.0.50 (Gentoo/Linux) mod_ssl/2.0.50 OpenSSL/0.9.7d DAV/2 SVN/1.0.6
PHP/4.3.8 configured -- resuming normal operations

Here's the scenario for me:
I access a directory accessible only by SSL on the web server that has a
.htaccess file that pops up an HTTP auth dialog. I enter the password correctly
and instead of going to a new page, my browser stays at the same page and I get
the "child pid xxx exit signal Segment fault (11)" in the logs. Any ideas?
creator: derheld42@derheld.net
jorton@redhat.com
text:
Sanry, please try 2.0.51, there are some mod_ssl segfault fixes in that release.

Anyone using "Apache/2.0.50 (Gentoo/Linux)": please contact Gentoo for support
since their are some non-standard patches in their 2.0 package.

creator: derheld42@derheld.net
text: I solved my problem by upgrading the pam_smb version from 2.0.0_rc5 to 2.0.0_rc6.
